Title: CTP761 Treasury Management Advisory Service
Description:
Derbyshire County Council is inviting tenders from suitable companies for the role of Treasury Management Adviser.  

Derbyshire County Council is the authority responsible for local government in the County of Derbyshire (excluding Derby City).  The existing treasury management consultancy contract expires on 31 July 2016, and the authority is seeking to procure an effective service to commence on 1 August 2016.

The contract will be for a period of up to four years (3 years + 1 year) subject to funding, service performance and the needs of the Council.
 
The authority wishes to appoint a Single Service Provider to deliver the requirements.

The contract is primarily to provide the Council with advice in respect of treasury management matters.  The role will include the provision of advice in respect of economics; the Council’s borrowing and temporary investment activity; government regulations on related topics; the CIPFA Code of Practice on Treasury Management, DCLG Guidance on Local Authority Investments, capital accounting and balance sheet issues and other related topics.

Derbyshire County Councils requires a minimum standard of over three years’ extensive experience in providing Treasury Management Advice and Consultancy to local authorities or an organisation of a similar size to Derbyshire County Council.
Derbyshire County Council currently manages the Treasury Management operations of the 
Derbyshire Pension Fund and the D2N2 LEP Growth Fund. 

A Combined Authority of councils in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire has been formed to
discuss options for mutual collaboration and working together. It is possible that 
additional Local Authority bodies may come under Derbyshire County Council’s Treasury
Management umbrella during the term of the contract. If this event occurs, then agreement
with regard to pricing revision will be based on the information provided in the tender 
submission.  Similarly Derbyshire County Council’s Treasury Management could be 
amalgamated under a Combined Authority Treasury Management. 

The purpose of seeking a single expert supplier in this field and utilising their experience and 
capability is to ensure the Council is spending their budget most effectively to achieve the 
desired outcomes it would not be able to gain alone in-house.  The supplier must 
therefore consistently evidence and deliver best value consultancy, showing its worth by 
considering and providing the right combination of price and quality.      


Immediately from award of contract, the supplier must be available to work with the Council to
carry out the service.  Upon expiry of the contract the provider must provide reasonable 
assistance to the Council, should the service transfer to another provider.

The annual budget for this service is between £12,000 and £20,000.  Bids exceeding this range will be deemed non-compliant.

Title: CTP771 For The Delivery Of A Self-Management Programme For Living With Long Term Conditions
Description:
Derbyshire County Council is seeking a provider for the design and delivery of a self-management programme for people living with long term conditions ('Programme'). The intervention will be designed to empower people that require support to better manage their long term condition (LTC) through a self-management model. The Programme must be available to people within the geographical area of the Derbyshire ('County'), with the exception of Derby City. 
In line with the national 'Talking Health' approach the Programme will target people living with LTCs; with face-to-face course sessions being delivered by trained volunteer tutor peers (themselves living with LTCs). The aim is to empower and support people by increasing their confidence, improving their quality of life, helping them to manage their condition more effectively and become an 'expert patient'. 
An expert patient is considered to be someone who:
•	Feels confident and in control of their life
•	Aims to manage their condition and its treatment in conjunction with healthcare professionals
•	Communicates effectively with professionals and is willing to share responsibility for treatment
•	Is realistic about how their condition affects them and their family
•	Uses their skills and knowledge to lead a full life 
 
The initial contract period is for 2 years commencing on 01 December 2018 to 30 November 2020, with the option to extend for a further two 12 month periods.

Title: CTP882 Falls Prevention: Research and Social Marketing Campaigns
Description:
The Council is seeking a provider with a proven track record over 3 years, to deliver a combined research and social marketing campaign(s) across the county of Derbyshire (excluding Derby City) to address the impact of and help prevent falls among older people.

The Council is looking to secure the services of an enthusiastic provider to create and deliver an innovative provision across three phases and take responsibility for working effectively with other stakeholders. The Council is prepared to consider a partnership bid to deliver each phase of the service.

The research element (Phase 1) will be undertaken over the first 6 months by examining international and national research but primarily conducting local research on adults' awareness of, attitudes towards and behaviours around falls and falls prevention. This would ideally include methods designed to identify population groups most at risk of falling in Derbyshire, qualitative research, and a review of the current provision of falls prevention services provided across the county.

Research will secure an evidence base to identify the awareness of, attitudes towards and behaviours around falls and falls prevention across:

•	The diverse communities of Derbyshire
•	Different age groups e.g. those who have fallen (65+), those at risk (65+), those affected i.e. carer's (all ages), those approaching older age (50-64)
•	Different genders
•	Different socio-economic groups
•	Specific targeted localities

The research in Phase 1 will determine the design of the social marketing campaigns, target cohorts and precise messages (Phase 2 & 3) which will be directed at all those at risk of or affected by falls. The provider will also be required to work with existing services delivering falls prevention interventions to ensure messages are tested and incorporated into current practice.  

Social marketing messages will be designed to achieve what works best, with whom and how it is best delivered for the specific targeted group, in order to create the greatest impact on awareness of, attitudes towards and behaviours around falls and falls prevention. These messages will need to be age-friendly and delivered via the correct mediums informed by the Phase 1 research. 

This service has a value of between £40,000 and £65,000 over a three year period.

Title: CETE090 Vital Valley: Old Spaces, Creative Futures
Description:
The Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site (DVMWHS) Partnership seeks to appoint a consultant to investigate, evaluate and report on options for a DVMWHS Visitor Centre as part of the North and East Mills site in Belper.  The DVMWHS Visitor Centre needs to be focussed on the heritage, stories and offer of the DVMWHS's 'Central Hub' as well as communicating and engaging people with the overall Outstanding Universal Value of the world heritage site. The Options Appraisal for a Visitor Centre is an opportunity to inform efforts to secure the heritage for the future, increase the range of cultural opportunities and contribute to sustainable tourism within the DVMWHS.

Once an option, with variations, has been established its feasibility needs to be fully assessed.  The assessment needs to cover capital and revenue costs as well as organisational requirements and skills to ensure its successful establishment and sustainable running.    

The DVMWHS Great Place Scheme is a £1.4m jointly funded National Lottery Heritage Fund and Arts Council England programme which aspires to engage and enable people to have a sense of pride in, and belonging to, the DVMWHS.

Old Spaces, Creative Futures is an activity that forms part of the Great Place Scheme.  The objective of this programme is to able creative reuse of the Belper Mills Complex to ensure they are a vital and vibrant part of the centre of the DVMWHS

Title: CETE079 Pleasley Visitor Hub Feasibility Study
Description:
This Pleasley Visitor Hub Feasibility Study will test the proposition of the area as a sustainable tourism hub, underpinned by the areas heritage assets, local environment and cycling as a zero-carbon leisure activity. 
The Study will provide an evidence based approach to future development, identifying what actions need to be taken in order to create sustainable growth.
The current proposition, as outlined within Appendix 2, is for illustrative purposes only, and the study will need to:
•	present the geographic scope of the development of the Hub, assessing how points of interest link spatially across the area, and explain how these contribute to the development of an alternative, sustainable short-break destination.
•	analyse the current offer and the potential for increased demand, presenting models of future growth with an assessment of uplift and an analysis of market capacity and competition. This should include a review of current accommodation and other facilities such as cafés and bike hire etc. that can attract the fun-family and active adult markets. And should suggest (and market test) the optimal range of activities as part of the development of the economic rationale that will underpin any future investment decisions.
•	test the economics of developing a sustainable tourism hub, by considering alternative economic models such as 'not-for-profit', 'willingness to pay' and 'voluntourism', alongside a more traditional economic model. Consideration should be given to: developing 'circular' and 'local' economies; promoting local products; zero-carbon or low-carbon development; using any development to support health and wellbeing; and to make a positive contribution to local cultural and environmental heritage by directing profits into future management. This work should be carried out with consideration for price-point, in order to develop the Hub as an affordable and sustainable alternative destination.

Title: Provision of Mental Health Service Receiver and Carer Engagement Service across Derbyshire
Description:
NHS Arden & Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit (NHS Arden & GEM CSU) on behalf of NHS Hardwick Clinical Commissioning Group (HCCG) acting as Lead Commissioner on behalf of the Derbyshire Clinical Commissioning Groups (including Erewash, South Derbyshire and North Derbyshire CCG's) and Derbyshire County Council are inviting suitably qualified providers to deliver a Mental Health Service Receiver and Carer Engagement Service across Derbyshire. 

Evidence suggests that engaging and involving patients in the planning, design and delivery of health and social care support and service provision can lead to more joined-up, co-ordinated and efficient services that are responsive to local community needs. Therefore Commissioner(s) are looking to procure a sustainable model that is fully inclusive and can provide a wide range of opportunities for service receiver and carer involvement by empowering them to be involved in the process. 

The key aims and objectives identified by the Commissioners will include; • Develop a sustainable model of engagement that provides value for money, is fully inclusive and provides a wide range of opportunities for service receiver and carer involvement in the commissioning process and improvements in service delivery • Develop an improved mechanism for the views of patients to be fed into service delivery, development and review • Ensure a consistent approach to engagement across geographical localities and across all communities • Maximise opportunities for engagement of seldom heard voices and ensure inclusivity of REGARDS characteristics. Engagement must also cover a wide range of mental health issues • Actively promote opportunities for engagement and involvement in localities and across all communities using a variety of means and methods, reaching groups both with and without a primary focus of mental health (where people affected by mental health problems may be represented • Support the development of and enable engagement from a wide range of organisations, communities and individuals across Derbyshire and Derby City • Co-ordinate and support communication between commissioners, providers, organisations, communities and individuals with an interest in engagement around mental health. This may include organisations whose primary focus is not mental health • Act as a central point to facilitate and co-ordinate the process of engagement • Develop and oversee a consistent approach to engagement, working with the coordinating group to set outcomes for priority areas. Set terms for engagement arrangements and structure with the spokes, resulting in engagement that is meaningful and effective • Provide advice and feedback to commissioners and providers on how opportunities for engagement can be improved • Support and develop collaborative working relationships with all stakeholders
Additional Text:

Title: P3511 Buxton Visitor Economy Strategy and Cultural Heritage Assets Review
Description:
High Peak Borough Council wish to appoint a suitably experienced and qualified consultancy to undertake a project to compile a Visitor Economy Strategy, Cultural Heritage Asset review and Destination Management Plan for Buxton, Derbyshire.

Buxton, population of approximately 23,000, is currently being transformed by an extensive programme of public and private sector funded regeneration projects based around its spa town heritage.  This is now culminating in the delivery of one of the UK's most  ambitious heritage tourism projects - the £50 million, five star hotel and spa in the Grade I listed Georgian Crescent and adjoining spa buildings.
The Town is now at a turning point and 2019 effectively sets a target for Buxton's visitor economy as a whole to be prepared and best equipped to maximise the benefits that the new development should bring to Buxton and the wider Peak District.

The Consultancy will report to the project Steering Group, which incorporates the town's key stakeholders (Buxton Crescent Heritage Trust, Buxton Opera House, the University of Derby, Vision Buxton, Derbyshire County Council and High Peak Borough Council).

Title: Request for Proposals for White Label Energy Agreement
Description:
Derby City Council (DCC) has taken the decision to offer a trusted local authority energy brand to its citizens as an alternative. DCC is seeking bids from OFGEM licensed energy providers that can deliver a white label gas and electricity product.

In December 2016 DCC and Derbyshire County Council conducted soft market testing to assess the viability of forming a white label arrangement with licensed energy providers. The soft market testing has helped us as an organisation clarify what is possible and how it aligns to our corporate goals. We have also taken the view that we will work independently, and not in conjunction with the County Council; however, we will explore possibilities for marketing in non-City areas in the future.

As part of this exercise, we are inviting companies to state how they will meet our vision and then propose draft terms and conditions for a white label arrangement.

This will take place using the East Mids Tenders e-tendering portal and you will need to register your company details at https://www.eastmidstenders.org.
